com.github.mmichaelis.describeme.core

Interface Describer

  • All Superinterfaces:
    Predicate<Object>
    All Known Subinterfaces:
    RecursiveDescriber
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    AbstractStreamDescriber, DefaultDescriber

    public interface Describer
extends Predicate<Object>

    A describer is responsible for describing specific objects where describing means to provide some representation as String.

    The components are delivered via the Service Provider. Do not forget to register Describers in 

    
 resources/META-INF/services/com.github.mmichaelis.describeme.core.Describer

    For describers supporting recursion into their elements implement RecursiveDescriber.

    Since:
    1.0.0
    See Also:
    RecursiveDescriber

    • Method Detail

      • test

        boolean test(@Nullable
             Object value)

        Validate if this describer is applicable to the given type. As the method gets the object to describe you might also distinguish if a Describer is applicable by the concrete value.

        Mind that an evaluation should be lightweight and should not depend on any mutable state of the object. This is because test() might be called multiple times (expect two times) for the same object.

        Specified by:
        test in interface Predicate<Object>
        Parameters:
        value - object to validate
        Returns:
        true if this describer can describe the given value; false otherwise
        Since:
        1.0.0

      • validatedValue

        @Nullable
default Object validatedValue(@Nullable
                                         Object value)

        Validates the value and returns it. If validation fails, thus if test(Object) return false an exception will be thrown.

        The default implementation just calls test(Object) for validation and throws an exception if the value is not valid.

        Parameters:
        value - the value to validate
        Returns:
        the value
        Throws:
        DescriberNotApplicableException - if describer is not applicable

      • describeTo

        @Contract(value="null, _ -> fail")
default void describeTo(@NotNull
                                                            Appendable appendable,
                                                            @Nullable
                                                            Object value)

        Add the description of the object to the given appendable.

        Default implementation uses DescriberProperties.MAX_COUNT which is configurable through system properties.

        Parameters:
        appendable - appendable to add value's string representation to
        value - the value to describe
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - if appendable is null
        DescriberIoException - if a failure occurs accessing the appendable
        DescriberNotApplicableException - if the value handed over to the Describer cannot be handled by this describer; you should have called test(Object) before
        Since:
        1.0.0

      • describeTo

        @Contract(value="null, _, _ -> fail")
void describeTo(@NotNull
                                                       Appendable appendable,
                                                       @Nullable
                                                       Object value,
                                                       int maxCount)

        Add the description of the object to the given appendable.

        On implementation it is recommended to use for example Objects.requireNonNull(Object) to validate the appendable and to use validatedValue(Object) to validate that the object really matches the requirements - just in case someone did not call test(Object) before.

        Parameters:
        appendable - appendable to add value's string representation to
        value - the value to describe
        maxCount - limits the elements to be added to the appendable; a negative value denotes unlimited - it is recommended to use DescriberProperties.UNLIMITED; the maxCount parameter does not promise any length of the appended String but should denote a limit the String representation for large objects; maxCount typically refers to list or array elements
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - if appendable is null
        DescriberIoException - if a failure occurs accessing the appendable
        DescriberNotApplicableException - if the value handed over to the Describer cannot be handled by this describer; you should have called test(Object) before
        Since:
        1.0.0
